title: Epic Scale Deathstorm Drop Pod Proxy

description.text:
An Astartes Deathstorm Drop Pod proxy model for Epic scale games (40k or armageddon etc).

[update 20171021: ran both models through netfabb]

Is a single piece print, the base is a standard 'dreadnought sized base' (20x20mm).
Digging the support out from under the missiles is a tiny bit tiresome but nothing that can't be achieved without a hobby knife, so a 5 minute job which is the time it takes to print the base... deal.

is a spiritual remix of this drop pod (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1008271) and this whirlwind (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:619995) though i only used the missile cones from the whirlwind and the general airfoil blade shape from the drop pod. anyway they were inspirational, so thanks to the respective modellers.

the choice of a 4 blade drop pod over 5 was entirely aesthetics and is probably unfluffy. wanted something different. wasn't because 4 is easier, i just felt like a 4 blader. oh, and it's deliberately a little shorter and squatter than the original DP.
might add some extra surface lumps for visual interest later but probably safer to rely on paint for such effects at this scale.

UPDATE: added deathstorm2.stl have printed this and it works fine. i prefer this model and 3 of 4 of my prints are this one (in pic 4 the front 3 are this one and the one at the back is v1).

This is a small game, i have at least for about 20 years on my shelf

Rules:

The rules are similar to the rules of the mill-game and easily to be learnt.

After the lots have been drawn for white and brown, each player receives 32 beads.
Now both players by turn try to build up a vertical, horizontal or diagonal lines (horizontally or vertically).
You can cross the opponent’s attempts to build mills by puttin your beads between his beads in time.

As soon as a player has built a mill, he may take away a bead from his opponent.
It is, however, only allowed to take beads which are seizable directly, that means which are on the top of a pin.
If a mill is closed, you may not take away a bead from this mill.

When all beads have been placed, you begin to build new mills, or to open and close existing mills by moving your beads.

The aim of the game is to take all beads from the opponent, or to block his beads in such a way, that he cannot move any longer.

Regeln:

Die Spielregeln sind ähnlich wie bei Mühle und leicht zu erlernen.

Nachdem die Farben weiß oder braun ausgelost wurden, erhält jeder Spieler 32 Perlen.
Beide Spieler setzen nun abwechselnd je eine Kugel ihrer Farbe auf einen beliebigen Stab und sind dabei bestrebt, eine Mühle zu bilden, d.h. 4 Perlen einer Farbe in einer waagrrechte, senkrechte oder diagonale (quer oder vertikal) Reihe zu stecken.
Die Versuche des Gegners eine Mühle zu bilden, können unterbunden werden, indem rechtzeitig Kugeln dazwischen gesteckt werden.

Sobald ein Spieler eine Mühle gesteckt hat, darf er dem Gegner eine Perle nehmen.
Dies gilt jedoch nur für Perlen, die direkt greifbar sind, d.h. die jeweils oberste Perle eines beliebigen Stabes.
Aus einer geschlossenen Mühle darf keine Perle genommen werden.

Sind alle Kugeln gesteckt, beginnt man durch Umstecken neue Mühlen zu bilden bzw. bestehende Mühlen zu öffnen und zu schließen.

Das Ziel des Spiels ist es, dem Gegenspieler alle Perlen abzunehmen oder die Perlen des Gegners zu blockieren, so dass er bewegungsunfähig wird.

You can find more information about this game on my badly maintained website, if you don't really know, how this should work.
The game is incomplete there, but you can find all about it, what you might want to know.
http://www.yves-tanas.de/kubik-muehle/
http://www.yves-tanas.de/cubic-mill/?lang=en

Hangers for the Oculus Rift CV1 headset. Two types, one that hangs over a drawer or cabinet door, and one that screws into the desk or whatever. Either will print without support, just put them flat-side down. You'll want to mirror the bracket in the slicer to get the left side. The spacer isn't really necessary, just makes it easier to keep them the right distance apart (160mm), and can be glued into the brackets for the hanging version. I suggest some rubber pads inside the hanging version's bracket to keep it from sliding and to adjust the fit.

Inspired by Jurat's design here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2069517 but should be stronger.

description.text:
Seeing as my CAD skill was very low when I started designing this case it has turned into a nightmare to edit. Anything and everything breaks upon editing a single sketch or extrusion. So I have decided to make a new case from the ground up with better editability.

The new version: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2627355

Having space for one 40mm fan and three 30mm fans this case has a very good amount of cooling.
Screen and power is designed to go up and out of the back.
It also has room for adding extra stuff inside the case.

If anyone wants something added comment and I will see if it is something I want to add to a future version.

This version needs support and you will need to orient the parts for optimal printing.

Update 2: Finally got around to printing some parts. And being that I'm just learning 3D printing and how to use CAD. I designed this without tolerances. Meaning that where the parts meet there is no space in between them. And you all know that 3D printers are not perfect this made it so that you had so sand the parts to be able to fit them together. So I went into the model to fix some tolerances.

Update 1: Side panel and top panel have untested latches(they are very small) for snapping the case together. Added indexing for fan shrouds and their panels for easier glueing.

print_settings.Notes:: You need support for the overhang at the one mounting point.  With my slicer (Cura), this puts support in the hex holes too, which is unnecessary and a bit of PITA to remove, but it comes out OK.

description.text:
This is highly inspired by KDan's Eachine Racer 250 Battery Tray
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1289398
Great design but unfortunately it will not work for my quad since it came with the SPRacing F3 Flight Controller. One of the support legs of KDan's battery tray was blocking the USB port of the controller.

I modeled this entirely from scratch, verified all dimensions on the quad itself, printed prototypes, and ultimately changed a few things (like the mounting legs). I did duplicate one feature not knowing exactly what it was for (the two tabs sticking down in the battery area) in hopes that the part will have greater utility for other people. I suspect it is for one of the other available controllers and was unnecessary for the F3.

You will need 2.5mm hardware for mounting the battery tray. 3x 12mm bolts, 1x 6mm bolt and 4x nuts.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1 mm

Infill:

Yes, but might not need to go 100%

Notes:

I had some problems getting the first layer(s) to print well. In particular, the two narrow corners of the part near the hex cut-out tended to have some voids and dragged material. Ultimately I slowed down the first layer and got better results. It looks like I still need some retraction when traversing from one area to another.

You need support for the overhang at the one mounting point. With my slicer (Cura), this puts support in the hex holes too, which is unnecessary and a bit of PITA to remove, but it comes out OK.
I'm new to 3D printing and have not used a CAD system in 25 years. I used TinkerCad to model it, which worked quite well.

comments.text: Thanks for the work you put in this.  I believe the tabs are just to create a broader surface to protect the battery some in the event of a crash.  The notch is where the the USB connector is on the CC3D board.  For use with the F3 boards, the notch is not needed.

description.text:
The perfect companion for your copy of "On Such a Full Sea!!" Finally, after months of printing, I allowed myself to upgrade to the truly amazing Makerbot Replicator. Now my prints look much more professional. This fish design is a 3D (2D really) representation of the fish design found at the beginnings of chapters in the novel "On Such a Full Sea", written by Chang-Rae Lee. The third picture above shows the original design from the book that I made this 3D file of. "We, at the height, are ready to decline.
There is a tide in the affairs of men,
Which, taken at the flood, leads on to fortune;
Omitted, all the voyage of their life
Is bound in shallows and in miseries.
On such a full sea are we now afloat,
And we must take the current when it serves
Or lose our ventures." -William Shakespeare, Julius Caesar The original picture of the koi is not mine. I made the 3D file representation, but the original picture is not of my design

description.text:
This is a quick and dirty carriage for dual Titan Aero on a modified Taz 5 using Piercet's OpenBuild V-Slot X Upgrade (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:866604). It may work on an un-modified Taz 5, but I haven't tried it.

The actual holder is based on pcsentinel's dual holder (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2240611 ).
I modified it to screw and heat insert onto a modified Taz 5 X mount which screws onto an Openbuild 20x80 universal gantry. This will allow me to test it on my gantry without removing my entire carriage.

My offset settings:
Right Extruder:
//#define HOTEND_OFFSET_X {0.0, 44.8} // (in mm) for each extruder, offset of the hotend on the X axis
//#define HOTEND_OFFSET_Y {0.0, 0.00} // (in mm) for each extruder, offset of the hotend on the Y axis
M218 T1 X44.80 Y0.00

BLTouch:
//#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 21 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
//#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -32 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
//#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -2.04 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]

There is a little gap in the horizontal of the extruder holder and the mount plate. This will allow you to shim the angle a few degrees to straighten your nozzles. I am using 2 different nozzles which are not the exact same length. (Hardened steel e3d and Ruby Olsson)

I will add a 30mm adapter plate (30mm_e3dv6_fan_adapter.stl) if you want to re-use the fans you have from the E3d v6 fins, or any other 30mm fan for the filament cooler. Current fans keep hitting the back right corner bed plate. I need to redesign.

This was mocked up in Tinkercad, so it's a bit less than pristine. If you can clean it up, please do!

description.text:
This is a remix of Brads Obi-Wan Kenobi's Episode 3 Lightsaber I love how easy his sabers are to print, I have simply looked at other peoples Obi Wan Ep4 Sabers and used Tinkercad to modify Brads Orignal models so all the parts will connect the same.

I also tried to keep this the same amount of parts to print its gone from 11 parts to 13 as I added my separated emitter face to this and the other extra part is the D-Ring so print time should be the same as before.

**Warning! If you use supports on the Radiator neck please check the overhang as it will be a lot of work to remove them from the finns my Cura only added supports to the socket area and not the finns so I had no clean up.

Supports should not be needed for any part personally I used supports touching buildplate for most parts that have a connection socket.

Im not 100% happy with the clamp might add more detail to it at a later date.

description.text:
Most of you must have seen F.R.I.E.N.D.S. There is a particular episode named;
"The One With Unagi" where Ross Geller explains to Rachel and Phoebe the concept of a remaining mind. However it is not called Unagi. Rather, it is termed as Zanshin.

Zanshin (Japanese: 残心) is a state of awareness, of relaxed alertness, in Japanese martial arts. A literal translation of Zanshin is "remaining mind". In several martial arts, Zanshin refers more narrowly to the body's posture after a technique is executed.

Here is a logo-esque model of the same. SVG was generated from a contribution from Moyashi Arts on Deviant Arts

Thank you!

Q23 Monitor Stand from Remix

This is a Monitor Stand I made from modifying http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2050885. I converted the STL from that into a CAD file, lopped off the top, and put a modification to accept a monitor Insert.

I bought this nice monitor MONDO CHEAP on Ebay without a stand. NOT A PROBLEM for a MAKER! The monitor is a HP 2011x and the mounting plate is stamped WF H37G0020-1 A4.

WANNA MAKE ONE? Chances are, you don’t need THIS specific stand. If you think your monitor is a close fit, try chopping it off the top in a design program and print it out on its own before you print the whole thing!

Another thing you can do, is to make a mock up piece that fits your monitor good, do a fill of the pocket in mine and then perform a Boolean operation with your mock-up! I’m uploading a STEP file so that you can import it to most standard cad programs.

I did my original work in Autodesk’s FUSION 360, including STL import, export, and STEP conversion and export. The slot for the Monitor Tongue goes through to the bottom of the cavity for easier support removal. I left the "MAKERBOT" stamp from the original model in-place. I don't know if I'm allowed to remove that from a Remix, or if I was supposed to take it out to prevent the appearance of an endorsement of my work! I'm sure they'll let me know!!!!

This was sliced and coded using ReplicatorG employing 2 shells (3 total) using PLA.

  • FlashForge Creator Pro (Similar to Makerbot Replicator 2)
  • Heated Bed 45 Celsius
  • Blue Painters Tape on bed, no further treatment
  • Print Temperature 220 degrees Celsius
  • SUPPORTS ARE REQUIRED to facilitate the building of the Monitor Tongue Cavity!!!!!
  • Feedrate 40 mm/s
  • Travel Feedrate 55
    (If anybody has more optimum feedrates, please share!)

title: Raspberry Pi Camera (v2) modified arm for Prusa i3 MK2

description.text:
I had to much vibration from the original arm so I did a quick and dirty remix of just the arm, get the rest of the parts from the original thing here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2194025

Also changed the mount under the heat bed to be shorter so it won't crash into the zip tie for the rod, and this version is mirrored from the original to mount it on the left side, you can mirror it back in your slicer if you want it on the right side.

EDIT 2017-05-29:

After adding changing to Tilted Adapter for Noctua https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2076234 with Velocity stack https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2211780 and Laminar Flow Fan plate https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:432630
If the camera was at a certain angle it would touch it during calibration, not wanting to reprint this arm and also wanting an angle closer to the middle to get a better view of the whole buildplate i now added an extension arm to the arm, it has an M4 nut trap, print with nut trap upside (i used a locking nut but i guess a normal will work fine).
First tests shows it works as expected, May update with photos some time later.

description.text: A cap for the inner bearing of a fidget spinner.

Printer:

XYZ Davinci Minimaker

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

15%

Experimental 3-bladed prop with the idea of noise reduction by notching the trailing edge. This borrows from the recent noise-reduction method used on the ducting of jet airliners, where notching is used to blend the air coming from high and low pressure areas. Figured the same just might work on propellers.

A plain version is also included for purposes of comparison or establishing a baseline in terms of performance.

--- Edit ---
Just did some more research. Seems the basis for this idea isn't that new.
https://www.google.com/patents/US4089618

Still, this general idea might be an interesting thing to look into. Quieter props do seem like something that would be useful for some R/C aircraft applications.
The middle bearing is a 608, as well as the outer bearings. The outer bearings slide onto the rods, and the cap should fit over. Designed in Fusion 360. This NEEDS support material.

title: Suspended Glass For Photography - 1-1/4 Inch Pipe Foot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This model can be used for many purposes. Nevertheless, it was mainly designed to suspend a sheet of glass in the air. This setup is used to take pictures of small objects without shadows.

This object is designed for standard 1-1/4 inch abs drain pipe.

You will need the following to make the photo suspended glass.

  • 4 x 1-1/4-inch drain pipe. Mines are 9 inches in length.
  • 4 feet.
  • 2 somewhat rigid rods. I have used steel rods, 3/16 inch in diameter.
  • 1 thin sheet of glass.
  • 1 large piece of paper or thin cardboard.

Drill holes near the top of the pipes to insert the rods.

comments.text: Where do you get the steel rods from? I'm assuming the PVC pipe is just something you can pick-up at a Home Depot or Lowe's, right?

comments.text: Pipes and rods comes from a hardware store like Home Depot (Reno Depot in Canada!). The cardboard comes from a Dollar Store along with the glass which is the glass of a picture frame.

description.text:
I have fond memories of playing West End Games' long out of print Assault on Hoth on my friends living room floor for hours.

This project has been in the back of my mind ever since I built my first printer.

The scales are all off, dictated by practicality. The Troops were printed with a 0.25mm extruder tip at 0.2 mm layers. Most of the result was printed with a 0.4mm tip at 0.2 - 0.3 mm layers.

The Snowspeeder is Jabberwock's model modified for easy printing without support.

The Shield Generator is Vincent1212's model, scaled down and dropped on a base.

All other models were designed from scratch.

Tips always appreciated...

Enjoy!

title: Z brace Camera Mount for Wanhao Duplicator i3, Maker Select. (C270 Tripod Remix)

description.text:
In an effort to find 'THE' camera mount, I downloaded and printed several from here but none really took me.

So I took some aspects from other mods and created this one.

Basically, all the others had extra "mounts" you had to attach to your printer and some were stand alone which would get moved around and you would have to realign the view.

This remix takes the C270 Tripod idea, and the swivel part from another camera mod and I basically bonded it with the Z-Axis mod which I already had installed.

So far I'm liking it.

Please if you can improve by all means do so..

Update
Moved the camera swivel mount farther to the outer side. I actually had the print bed hit the camera arms so I decided to move it. I also made it beefier and rounded a bit more on it.

I don't have a picture yet as I'm in the middle of a 12hr print. I've uploaded them with the prefix "B_" B for BEEFY. :)

Maker Select 3d V2

Yes

50% (same as z-axis mod since it's the feet)

Notes:

Since it's the front feet of the z-axis mod, please take the same print settings of 50% infill or more and if possible hexagonal pattern)

Other notes are on that mods page: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:921948

You'll also need one M3-18 (I think, I grabbed one from my stash that fit) and a basic M3 nut to mount the swivel arm.

I only included the swivel arm from Googliola's mount. The rest you'll have to get from the other mods:

Logitech C270 mount and arms here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1228521
Longer/Shorter arms from my remix here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2283437
The rest of the Z-Axis Mods Here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:921948

title: Asymmetric Balanced Fidget Spinner: Penny, Nickel, Quarter

description.text:
https://youtu.be/azr-qgd7Hsg
There is more than meets the eye with this fidget spinner. It is balanced even though it has 3 different weights. The calculation that went in to figuring out what angles each lobe needed to be in relation to each other is pretty neat.

Printer:

Makerfront i3Pro XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Notes:

Printed with PETG. .3mm first layer, .2mm other layers.

Balancing

All coins should press in. I tried to use mostly new coins. The fidget was not absolutely perfectly balanced and was a tad light on the penny lobe. To cure this, I removed one new penny(.088oz) and added an older one (.106oz). The 4 nickels I used weigh .702 oz, 5 pennies = .459oz, and 4 quarters .804oz.

I have fidget caps here - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2303052

My kids wanted a fidget spinner. I didn't see any designs I liked. Using OpenScad, I made a few fidget spinners with all nickels and all pennies. I wondered if I could design one with 3 different types of coins that was also balanced. Challenge Accepted!!
Explaining this is a little  dicey for me.  For the sake of keeping this short, I am going to say things I think are true even if I am not absolutely certain of it.

• A flat object's center of gravity is where that object is rotationally balanced. (like a car tire)
  • If you lay a flat object on a surface and draw x and y coordinates across its center of gravity, the sum of the gravitational forces above and below the x coordinate will be equal, as will the sum of the forces to the left and right of the y axis.
  • A fidget spinner must have its center of gravity in the center of the bearing hole to be rotationally balanced.
  • We will be balancing the object in the x direction and the y direction.
  • As if the fidget spinner was on a fulcrum located in the center of the hole of the bearing, we will calculate forces by using length times weight in both the x and y direction separately which will yield two equations and two unknowns.
  • The amount of material used in connecting each coin to the bearing and its effect on changing each coin lobe's center of gravity is negligible.

• I recall from school that the sine of 30 degrees is .5 and the cosine of 60 degrees is .5. This is relevant to me because if I have a circle on and x,y chart with a radius R and an object is 30 degrees above horizontal on the circle, it is exactly half of R in the y direction (up). Play with this circle to get a better feel for it - https://www.mathsisfun.com/algebra/trig-interactive-unit-circle.html.
  • A typical 3-lobed fidget spinner is balanced because it forms a perfect triangle with lobes equal distance apart from each other at 120 (=360/3) degree angles from each other. Picture the rotational circle of the fidget spinner on an x,y graph and place one lobe at the top.
    • You can visually see that the spinner is balanced in the x direction (left & right) along the y axis because each side is a mirror image of the other. Mathematically you can see that the left side weight multiplied times the distance from the x axis is equal to the right side weight multiplied times the distance from the x axis. (ignoring the top lobe)
      • The formula for this is Lsin(y)W=Lsin(x)W where L is Length and W is weight. Dividing both sides of the equation simplifies this to sin(y)=sin(x). Since a normal fidget spinner is a perfect triangle, y is 120 and x is 240 and the sines of both of those is equal to .866
    • The balance in the y direction (up & down) across the x axis is not obvious but can be proven by math. For simplicity sake, lets assume the weight of each lobe is 1 and the distance from the center of each lobe is one. The force above the x axis is 1 weight times 1 length = 1 Force. The force below the x axis is 2 weights, one on each lobe, times their lengths from the x axis (not the center because we are balancing only in the y direction now). Since each weight is 120 degrees from the top they are only .5 length below the x axis. So their combined force is 2 weights times .5 lengths which is equal to 1 force.
      • The formula for this is Lcos(y)W+Lcos(x)W=LW. Dividing both sides of the equation by L and W results in cos(y)+cos(x) = 1. In the case of a perfect triangle fidget spinner cos(120)+cos(240)=1 which equals .5+.5=1.

description.header: Formula to balance an asymetrically weighted Spinner
description.text:
• Start with the formulas we learned above. Lsin(y)W=Lsin(x)W and Lcos(y)W+Lcos(x)W=LW.
  • Replace W with Q, N, P for QuarterWeight, NickelWeight, and PennyWeight and assume the quarter is at the top of our circle. This yields - Lsin(y)N=Lsin(x)Q and Lcos(y)N+Lcos(x)Q=LP.
  • We can see now that as long as the L remains constant, which it will be because we decided that makes things much easier, the formulas are now sin(y)N=sin(x)P and cos(y)N+cos(x)P=Q
  • I made some careful calculations, weighed a lot of coins, and weighed several test print partials of my fidget spinner. I did learn that not all coins have the same weight depending on how old they are. For my spinner, I determined the weight of each lobe by measuring the coin weights and the 3D printed material encapsulating it. For quarters (4), this was .861 grams; Nickels (4) = .758 grams; Pennies (5) = .494 grams

• We now have two equations and two unknowns. sin(y).758=sin(x).861 and cos(y).758+cos(x).861=.494
  • People who are really good at trig can probably solve for x in one equation and plug that into the other equation to come up with a single formula for x and y. I am not one of those people.
  • I found a great website that would graph this for me (https://www.desmos.com/calculator/9fe5yscpyv).
  • The intersection of both graphs is the answer. But the answer is in radians, so convert it to degrees. (Google that. It is a little confusing). x = 84.0771446604 degrees and y = 61.1246272748. Unfortunately, the way I set this up was not 100% correct and the formula ignores negatives. For example, cos(60) = .5 and cos(120) = -.5. The answers my formula derives will always be less than 90 degrees. To get the answer I really want I need to take x and subtract it from 180 and that is the angle the nickels have from the pennies (95.92285534). The quarters are 180+61.12462720 degrees from the pennies (241.12462720)
• I used those angles in and OpenScad design. I kept the center of the coins equal distance from the center of the fidget spinner.

• Print fidget spinner and assemble.
  • Spin the fidget and feel that it is balanced.
    • Discuss rotational symmetry and why most fidget spinners are rotationally symmetrical.
    • Why is this fidget balanced?
  • Given that each coin's center remains equal distance away from the center of the fidget bearings, what would happen if any of the coins at any other angle to each other?
  • Discuss how to formulate the equations that will determine what angles the coins need to be from each other. (Refer to "How I Designed This" section)
  • Calculate the angles given the weights of the different sets of coins.
  • Measure that the angles of the fidget match your calculations using: Quarters (4) = .861 grams; Nickels (4) = .758 grams; Pennies (5) = .494 grams

• 22mm Bearing
  • 4 quarters
  • 4 nickels
  • 5 pennies
  • caclulator
  • web browser with internet access.
  • protractor

• Trigonometry
  • Engineering
  • Graphs
  • Center of Gravity
  • Algebra
  • Physics
1 hour
Link to graph of 2 equations and 2 unknowns on desmos.com Interactive Trigonometry Circle

comments.text:
Nice. I also get the sense scanner, and i offen have lost target problem, do you have some advises.
thank you ;)
comments.author: mrzou

comments.text: Try using a solid, (dark if possible) background with as few details as possible. The sense tends to get confused on an object when there are objects in the background. My wife scanned me for this print. She had never used it before and did great. It gets tough when you fall off of the target, but a solid background should help (perhaps a drape or sheet). If not, be sure the lens is clean, and getting an extension usb helps a lot! I use a Macbook for my sense. Hope some of that helps! Good luck!
comments.author: mrzou

comments.text: It takes some getting used to with the cord, distance from subject, and lighting, but it can knock out a great scan in a minute or two. Full body subjects are a task, but would probably be easier doing sectioned scans, then editing them together. Overall, I'd buy another, but may wait until their next scanner. This scan alone, made it worth the purchase.

description.text:
A linear servo for HiTEC HS-645MG Ultra Torque metal gear servos capable of lifting ten pounds, with a 50mm reach. After searching thingiverse for a robust, 3D printable linear servo, I found several with very fine teeth which would not provide enough holding force and would require tight tolerances. Furthermore, the 3D-printed gears had nothing to prevent slipping on the servo axle. I designed my own last night using a HiTEC MG servo and created a gear with holes aligned to the HiTEC servo horns. It can work with any HiTEC servo of this size. The metal gears just make it stronger for robotics and less likely to wear out.

5-16-2017 Fixed three hole positions in the servo horn gear. The HiTEC Servo Horn Wheel has three rings of holes arranged in groups of three, ten degrees apart from nearest neighbors, at radial distances of 7mm, 8.5mm, and 10mm. Previous gear had only three holes in the 8.5mm radius ring and nine holes in the 10mm radius ring. Also added a bevel to the screw holes on the gear. Also added 1/8-in screw holes to the ends of the LINEAR ARM for more attachment options. I also widened the clearance for the gear in the fixture. Servo position may be adjusted by adding washers to servo mount screws if needed.

Added a square servo horn mounted gear. Most HiTEC servos come with a square horn (but not the HiTEC HS-645MG), simplifying the gear attachment to one screw.

description.text:
this is just a concept. the idea is that when you pour the fluid into the funnel the pressure would push it through the tube back into the funnel starting the process again. perpetual motion is possible but you can't power something with it because eventually, friction will come into play stopping the perpetual motion. though this perpetual motion concept doesn't work for a different reason. when you pour the fluid in gravity pulls it down. so instead of it pouring out the other end, it overflows where the funnel is. kind of like when you are pouring coffee and this Russian supermodel comes in and your cup overflows. and you burn your hand. its the same with the perpetual wheel by Richmac (the featured one). gravity pulls down at the balls stopping it from turning. Law of conservation of mass states that matter can be changed from one form into another, mixtures can be separated or made, and pure substances can be decomposed, but the total amount of mass remains constant. energy has mass if you didn't know. you can never truly create mass or delete it. it will come from somewhere or go somewhere. as a much smarter person than i once said," you cant get something from nothing or make something nothing".

more info in the coments

comments.text: How long does it run, if at all?
comments.author: Malcolmhead

comments.text: not long probably but if you want to make one that runs a tad longer I'm pretty sure that if you get a funnel and a flexible plastic pipe where the end of the pipe that liquid comes out is smaller than the end where it goes in.don't take my word for it I've never tried it.this design doesn't have the smaller end. like I said I was just going for a concept piece. if you try to kink the hose/pipe or suck on the end to start a vacuum, it won't work. gravity would stop it. another factor that I didn't mention but wouldn't make a difference is molecular weight.this just means the number of hydrogen bonds that the molecules can make causing molecules to act like a chain. a liquid that has a very high molecular weight is Polyethylene Glycol which is fun to play around with. so if I was to pour a small amount of the Poly. Glycol out of a cup, the whole thing would empty pulling its strands of molecules with it as it pours just taking more P.G. with it. the only way to stop is to physically break the bond. if you but P.G. in it gravity would stop it despite its viscosity and molecular weight. so what I'm getting at is that gravity is the main, really the only limiting factor, and the molecular weight is just a bonus. I hope I didn't bore you too much have a good day and good luck experimenting if you do. though I would like people to make this it is not the best way to experiment. try it with the funnel and pipe

I designed this end cap to be able to remove them without breaking them. I have printed a dozen in every color I have, and the neighborhood kids love to swap them in and out for the spinners we print, as well as the ones they buy or trade for with friends. Not much to it, but they like the variety of colors.

Tip for printing... don't just print 1 at a time. Print at least 4. This allows the thin layers at top to cool while the printer moves to the next piece. I do 12 at a time, and have a bowl full now.

comments.author: chrisp56

comments.text:
I added an exploded view... You will need to glue the small gear parts to line up with the cover plates, and also the black round parts need to be glued to the shaft during assembly (offset 180 degrees from each other). I printed mine at a .75 scale and used .250-20 bolts and nuts, if printed at full size i believe a .375-16 fits through the holes.. but you could probably drill them out to any size that works for your hardware. I did a lil sanding on some of the parts to get them to function smoothly, and tapped out the shaft and handle hole to get the bolt to thread properly (since it was scaled down).
Hope that helps. (16 parts total)

description.text:
I designed this Owl Fidget Spinner to work in smaller, kid sized hands. Works for adults too!

This requires 608ZZ bearings.

The bearing covers also have a small lip to prevent the covers from accidentally touching the bearing and slowing it down. You can squeeze these covers firmly without deforming them and slowing the bearings.

title: E3D Titan Extruder Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Behold ye Titans of 3D Printing! I submit to you a mount for the much acclaimed E3D Titan extruder. It is meant to attach to Toolson's X-carriage mount, though you could use it on any other carriage as long as it has the correct hole spacing (or you own a drill ;) )

Main goals of the design:
1) Simple
2) Lightweight
3) Easy access to remove the hotend assembly for cleaning/maintenance/swapping
4) Easy upgradablilty through attachment holes
5) Beautiful aesthetic (it's 2017 people....why do our 3D printers still look blocky and like a five year old designed them out of legos?)
6) Compact with the hotend itself as close to the X-axis rails as possible

The prox sensor mount is completely optional and features hex-nut holders underneath. It is designed for a 12mm-OD sensor. If you have a different sensor you'd like to add to the mount, the hole spacing simply 40mm between the two 3.2mm holes. Depending on your plastic choice and how flexible it is, you may want to add the prox mount simply to stiffen the assembly, even if you don't use it.

Printer:

Prusa Mendel (yeah....the really old one)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

I would suggest printing the model in ABS or another stiff, temperature-resistant plastic due to the proximity to the hotend and the heated bed. The Z-step height doesn't matter all that much.

The mount itself should be printed with a brim to prevent curling/deformation during printing. Use of supports is optional. The main overhangs will end up being hidden, so this isn't a huge concern.

The optional proximity switch mount should NOT be printed with a brim or supports to avoid any issues with the nut holes on the bottom from getting messed up.

Recommended

I'd highly recommend vapor polishing the mount (if done in ABS) and allowing it to "dry" for 48 hours before mounting this on a printer. The vapor polishing will help to strengthen the thin walls by chemically welding the layers together. The drying period is required to make sure the plastic has regained its original stiffness to avoid ghosting in your prints. The walls are necessarily thin due to how the E3D needs to be mounted which means they get "rubbery" when exposed to acetone.

Conversely, you can try to simply wipe down the surface with acetone, but it will not provide the same level of strengthening.

ALL HAIL TINKERCAD

Yeah, yeah, tinkercad is not exactly the most "professional" software to design parts in. But, it's free, relatively powerful, and stupid easy to use. It is also more easily accessible by schools, students, and less affluent folks who may not be able to pay for something like Solidworks or AutoCAD.

The link for the extruder mount should you want to tinker around with it (no pun intended):
https://tinkercad.com/things/36VwnE1wALR

The link for the prox mount (same deal):
https://tinkercad.com/things/iUaA4N2oMg0

print_settings.Notes:: I'm sorry I have no advice about printing.  I can only leave it up to you, the expert, to figure out whether your printer is up to the job.

description.text:
This is a suncatcher or ornament kind of thing. It can stand or hang, it's best with light behind it, and it's more for looking than handling.
To make it you'll need a decent 3D print of this STL file. By decent I mean the part has grooves 1mm wide by 2mm deep, facing all directions, and they have to be completely clear without any powder or cruft. I got mine at Shapeways, it's $24 here. No markup.

Printer:

SLS

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

I'm sorry I have no advice about printing. I can only leave it up to you, the expert, to figure out whether your printer is up to the job.

Cut transparent inserts

You'll also need need 12 shaped pieces of translucent sheet that's less than 1mm thick and moderately stiff. Reasonably heavy acetate should work. Cardstock would work, though to my mind transparency is the whole point of the thing.
I used dichroic window film that I got at decorativefilm.com. I used Glitter but any should work. I stuck it to itself back to back, so it's double-thick and double-bright, and this also gets rid of the problem that it comes on a roll and doesn't want to be flat. It's weird stuff. It reflects yellow and transmits teal or magenta depending on the angle, so it's really trichroic...I have no idea what physics is going on here, but it's pretty.
I cut it using a Silhouette Cameo, and I've included a .studio3 file for that. You'll have to figure out cut depth for your material. (I used an autoblade set to 8, since as noted my film was super thick.) There's also a DXF file in case you have some other kind of cutter, and a PDF for if you just have scissors.

Assemble it

If you want to hang it as a suncatcher, tie a thread to the hanging hole before putting in the panes.
Slide your sheet pieces into the slots of each face. The slots need to be completely clear, if there's powder you'll need to dig it out with a toothpick or something. The last pane is fiddly because it's easier to do this while you can touch the sheet from both sides. But you'll get it.
Then hang it up, wait for sunlight, and be happy.

author: Problex

description.text:
Magic theme consistent box for dice or other game stuff.
Can hold up to 12pcs/16mm, 15pcs/14mm or 24pcs/12mm D6 dice.
Max stuff height 16mm.
Hinge axel size 3mm. Found one from forum (http://forums.mtgsalvation.com/showthread.php?t=483261) that was made from lot of stacked cards. For this you only need 4 card.

• Print two frame and three hinge.
  • Pick four cheap card and glue two of them to "inside" (top) of both frame.
  • Cut center of the card away so only card frame will leave in printed frame.
  • Glue other two to bottom side of both frame.
  • Take cutted center piece and glue that inside both frame.
  • Find some axel to connect parts together.
  • If hinge (axel) is little tight, box might stay close without clasp. Else make some clasp to keep it close when not in use.

description.text:
Templates that I use to create Midori style notebooks. These are setup for A5 inserts and if you plan to have a notebook with more than a couple of inserts the 350mm wide template provides a better fit.

I cut the templates from 3mm MDF and then use them as a template to cut the leather and drill through with a 3mm drill bit to make the holes for the elastic. Ideally, they could be cut on a laser, unfortunately, my laser is too small to cut them.

The leather is then folded and clamped between a couple of sheets of mdf or ply to help keep it closed.

2mm elastic is used to hold the inserts inside the notebook and 2.2mm for the outer binding.

The pen holder can be made from a money clip and an offcut of leather.
definitely solid and supports, scale based on fitment unscaled will fit on a 6.8 mm post

This is Release 1 for a case for the BADGEr_v4.1 which is an eInk Badge you can get from Seeedstudio at http://www.seeedstudio.com/depot/badgerv4-p-1587.html When it's complete it will be held together by 1/4" x 1/16" magnets. I've already started thinking about Revision 2 of this case. It doesn't have any lateral shear resistance since it's being held together with only magnets. Adding a latch on one corner would give it strength but still allow fast/easy removal. I want to shorten the depth of the back and front. On the front, particularly, I want the display on the same level as the front plate. badger_case.scad is the OpenSCAD model.
badger_case.stl are both the top and bottom pieces in one file.
badger_case_bottom.stl is the bottom of the case
badger_case_top.stl is the top of the case. This is a Work In Progress! Code is in github at https://github.com/melodybliss/3d/tree/master/BADGEr Latest change: after first real test print, realized forgot opening for the header. Also shifted the mounting holes over by 1.5mm and shifted the power switch opening by a couple of mm Next change: magnet isn't going into it's slot well, so increased the size of the magnet's hole slightly and parameterized the border for the magnet.

Thinner. Higher tolerance.

description.text:
I often transport my DJI Mavic Pro without a battery installed. This very simple filler prevents the propellers from being bent down when folded, and also (maybe) adds a bit of extra strength to the basic frame.

The model was created by hand in OpenSCAD as a simple approximation of the battery shape, but it sits in the gap quite snuggly. It does not clip in. If someone has more time then perhaps a more accurate 3D model of the battery could be made, but this fits my needs for now.

title: Star Trek Bird of Prey version 2.0

description.text:
05-15-2017 : Added a stand for the Bird of Prey ;o)

05-14-2017 :
This model was based on nd4spd1919 model (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1426990). I remade the guns in Tinkercad to be able to print them correctly and i separated the guns and nose because i wasn't able to achieve a good result of those pieces when removing the supports.

I made 2 versions of the nose and guns because i noticed that sometimes the quality of the print varies when an object is oriented on different axes.

I used Autodesk Netfabb to repair the mesh of the original model to be able to print it without problems. I used Meshmixer to separate the nose and guns from the main body and i used Tinkercad to create the pegs and holes that fit together.

description.text:
MeCreator2 - Plexiglas Hood & Accessories

Update 13.10.2017:
Since my Printer also safely arrived in Singapore and i finally had time to unpack all my stuff.
I had an idea and just designed an spoolholderarm because all old ones are designed to snap in where my hood is. I come up with an easy solution it snaps in on the side and the weight of the spool holds the arm in place. Then I mirrored it and now even have 2.
The plexiglas piece on top of the hood i just switched with the plexiglas on the back

I love this big Screw Design for easy Removing the spool from this Thing https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2026642
I used it and just Screwed it with a 8mm Bearing and some washer from a fidget spinner (No tears I hate this things) (Left side is Remixed / Right side is original the Difference is only the distance of the Bearings inside the Screw)

I will upload soon.

Update:
I just for Information I added some pictures from additional changes i made recently on my printer.

  1. I always had issues with my cooling fan. I recently found out it was completely blocked by support material left from the geetech printed fan duct version. I recommend checking this if you have issues too. I decided NOT to go anymore with the geetech version of cooling i installed now this easy Design https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2408527
    Now it rocks and the best part is now you can see whats going on nothing is blocking your sight anymore.

  2. I also want to share the Thing i used for the x axis cable chain.
    after just a few prints the cables where almost broken because of the sharp frame.
    I used https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:124700 and the best part is it fits 1:1 you don't have to change anything there.
    I´ve printed:
    13x cable_chainunit.stl
    1x cablechaindrive_small.stl (Fits perfect you need 10mm long M3 Screws instead of the 8mm ones)
    1x cable_chainmount.stl (You can tape it or mount it on the frame)
    I splitt the right Plexiglas side for the purpose of supporting it on 13mm hight.
    Its not necessary because it is self supporting. I just wanted it perfectly even.
    The cables fit through without dissembling!!!

title: Low-friction Spool Roller for TEVO Black Widow Top Mount Spool Holder (85mm/120mm)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
"Low-Friction Spool Roller" was designed to be used with the "Top Mount Spool Holder"* by bdwalker which sits atop the TEVO Black Widow printer.

I was worried filament spools dragging on a fixed shaft might cause the extruder head to bounce, so I designed a spool tube with rollers that can be used in place of a static tube.

"Low-Friction Spool Roller" suspends the inner core of the filament spool on three rollers to let it spin freely with almost no friction. The 3D printable rollers are borrowed from Creative Tools' Universal Stand-Alone Spool Holder** (an excellent holder), even the shafts for the rollers are just cut lengths of 1.75mm filament.

Although the wall of the tube is strong enough to support any 1kg filament spool, additional structural support was added to equalize heat distribution to prevent warping & splitting when printing in ABS on an open bed printer. Flats were added to keep the tube from rotating in the cradles. It's designed to be printed w/o any need for internal supports although a Touching Buildplate or Raft is recommended.

Printed using 1.75mm ABS in CURA v15.04.6 w/Support @10% Touching Buildplate w/Brim.

STL's are included for two tubes: 85mm and 120mm (the latter for holding wider 4-color 1.3kg spools). Each STL includes three printable roller wheels.

Top Mount Spool Holder by bdwalker: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1743661
Universal Spool Holder by Creative Tools: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:508896

description.text:
Use zip ties to attach your preferred bottle-rocket-launching bottle to this base. Your bottle will be tilted at 10 degrees from vertical for good launch height plus directional control. The base makes a much more stable platform.  
Always follow all proper safety procedures, of course. If you don't know how to safely use fireworks, don't use fireworks. [/safetynagging]

• Print launchpad. Should fit within the build envelope of a Prusa quite nicely. If your printer is smaller, you could scale it down quite a bit without compromising fit with smaller bottles.

  • Consume bottle of favored beverage. If it is alcoholic, preferably well in advance of playing with explosives. I suggest a 22 oz. Red Hook ESB, but any similarly-sized bottle will fit, and smaller bottles work too.

  • Secure bottle with zip ties. Please.

  • Aim away from people, structures, and flammable scenery.

  • Launch bottle rockets. Bask in the glee of explosives, even if the payload is small.

author: Bijoncradu

description.text:
Vous avez toujours rêvé de pouvoir imprimer n'importe où, alors ce modèle d'imprimante est fait pour vous!
Comme vous pouvez le constater, l'imprimante n'est pas encore totalement terminée. Alors pourquoi la publier prématurément? Et bien, pour avoir quelques avis extérieurs afin de pouvoir affiner mon travail.
En effet, pour les plus observateurs d'entre vous, vous conviendrez qu'il y a quelques différences entre la théorie (le plan) et la pratique...
Et de ce fait, il ne vous suffira pas de télécharger tous les fichiers pour arriver à une imprimante fonctionnelle. Il vous faudra faire chauffer un peu vos méninges ;)

La suite arrivera petit à petit.
Et dû au changement de dossier, l'assemblage aura certainement quelques erreurs

1° : le câblage

Pour le moment l’intérieur ressemble à un énorme plat de spaghettis, je suis donc en train de réfléchir à l'ajout de "chain wire"

2° : légère vibration du portique

Lors des mouvements de remplissage surtout, il y a une oscillation de 0.1 à 0.2 mm (ce qui est vraiment beaucoup). Pour y remédier, je projette l'incorporation de fil de triangulation ne nécessitant aucun montage-démontage et les glissières à rigidifier surtout (point suivant)

3° : les glissières

Dans les plans originaux, elles devaient être usinée soit en acier, soit en alu, mais comme je n'en ai pas, j'ai trouvé autre chose ; des profilés en acier, laiton et alu qui savamment assemblés font office de glissières mais par contre, ne sont pas suffisamment rigides pour éliminer les petites vibrations, surtout au niveau des moteurs d'axe Z.

Glissière supérieure Glissière inférieure Sources

Extrudeur trouvé sur le net
Fichier carte RAMPS 1.4 sur le net

Je retrouverai les liens d'ici peu

et modèle de l'alimentation : DPS-800GB A

comments.text: Sympa comme projet, j'ai jeté un œil sur la photo, il faudrait essayer de mettre un système très rigide pour le blocage verticale. A mon avis les petits bras que tu as ne sont passer long

description.text:
I wanted to play with OpenCV and stereo visión so I've built this design for 2 Creative Live! Synch HD cameras. The center piece is there to hold an optional Laser (12mm in diameter) as I saw some projects using a single camera with a laser module to detect distances and thought it would be nice to have it in place just for fun (and the cameras need some spacing between them to be able to screw it to the board.

The distance between lenses is about 70mm.

On windows it can be tested with Stereoscopic Multiplexer:
http://www.3dtv.at/Downloads/Index_en.aspx

FreeCAD files included (A bit messy though)

title: Mamba-X ESC Holder for Traxxas Slash 4X4

description.text: I upgraded my Traxxas Slash 4X4 motor and ESC to the Castle Creation's 1415-2400KV Motor and Mamba-X water prof ESC. The Mamba-X ESC dose not have any mounting holes so I would have to use Velcro or 2-sided tape to hold it in place and the Mamba-X's power switch would also need a way to mount it so it doesn't bounce around. Took about 6 design changes to get what would work. This two part design has the main holder and clamp and uses mounting holes that are already part of the Traxxas Slash 4X4's chassis so there is no drilling required to the main chassis. The main holder has accommodations for the Castle Creation Mamba-X's power switch. You will need two M3 x 22mm button or cap screws for mounting.

Printer:

Qidi Tech X-One

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I used PLA at 25% infill, but 15-20% could work too. I didn't use ABS because the ESC does get warm and PLA is better for that than ABS.

I used TinkerCad, digital calipers and about 6 revs and I think I could improve it a little more, but it is good the way it is.
To print I used Simplify3D slicer to generate the gcode for my Qidi Tech One-X 3D printer.
I printed the design with PLA.

author: some1special

description.text:
A portable pocket sun dial designed for 50Â°N.
For details of where 50Â°N is on earth see here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/50th_parallel_north
  • The big hole in the base near the hinge makes it easy to attach a string to hang it around your neck, attach it to your bag(pack) or to make it easier to find it in your pocket.
  • You can close (fold) the pocket sun dial like a pocket watch if you want to put it in your pocket. (not shown in the pictures)
    • Thanks for visiting.
    Chris Created with FreeCAD http://www.freecadweb.org/

• Print the base.
  • Print the lid.
  • Print 2x the plug. (optional)
  • Put a compass in the hole of the base. (optional) north of the compass should point to the lid. (see picture)
  • Assemble the lid and base so that the holes of the hinge align. Put a piece of filament (3mm) through the hole to make the hinge work. If you don't have filament with 3mm diameter you can use a M3 screw (not tested).
  • Put a string through the hole in the lid and the base as seen in the picture.
  • Tie a knot at each end (on the outer side) to fix the string.
  • Then you can hide the knots and close the holes form the outside with the plugs. (optional)

description.header: The face of the lid should be facing south (north of the compass needle directing to the lid like shown in the picture) and the base should be horizontal in order to read the time of day. In direct sunlight you can read the time of day on the face of the lid.
description.text:
• horizontal left mark on the lid -> 6:00h in the morning
    vertical down mark on the lid -> 12:00h (midday)
    horizontal right mark on the lid -> 18:00h
    in summertime for time correction reasons there is a 1 hour difference...
  • At night you can use a flashlight in order to use the compass for orientation.
    • Enjoy.

comments.text: VERY cool idea! I am at N44 so it would be nearly accurate for me. It would be very cool if you could spare the time to make lids for ever 5 degrees latitude and upload them. Especially if the lids are easily replaceable. So when people go on a camping trip in a different latitude, they can install the lid they need. Years ago I carried a sundial daily as my "watch" when I was a camp counselor. It was accurate to about 4 minutes. It got me to my classes on time all summer without fail. (except on rainy days when I had to ask others what time it was)

title: Prusa i3 MK2 - Extruder Fan Shroud (30mm)

description.text:
This is a fan shroud that clips onto the 30mm extruder fan of a Prusa i3. It helps direct air into the inlet of the fan, and prevents wash from being thrown out of the side of the fan onto the print bed.

When I first started printing ABS with the Prusa i3 MK2S, I noticed some wash coming off the bottom of the fan for the extruder. This caused the back left corner of all my prints to warp severely.

Since installing it, I have not had an issue with warping and I cannot feel any air escaping the sides of the fan inlet.

Installation Note: One side of the clip is offset slightly lower, this goes on the back or left side of the fan. There is a plastic piece on the extruder body that this clip goes below.

An OpenSCAD version of the Icthys with various forms
I saw various fish on Thingiverse, but they were in non-parametric forms (one even commented that it was really too small). So this one is in OpenSCAD, to be scaled to whatever size you like, or embossed on other prints, etc.

In the OpenSCAD file there are various functions that produce standard fish, and other modules that do portions of fish, so you can mix them in various ways. My intent is to provide a base for people to build on. Currently these have no words or text, just the emblem itself. Available emblems are:
Fish (Icthys, Christian symbol for mutual identification)
Darwin Fish (facing right, with feet)
FSM Fish (no fins, eye stalks with optional iris, and tentacles)

comments.text: Thank you! Was looking for just a plain fish that is easy to scale!

comments.text: Some will like one, some another - the point was mostly to make a usable base and see what other people come up with. The basic emblem is something that a lot of people have made variations of already, so there are ideas out there, it is flat and fairly simple, so should be printable on most people's machines, and is a good vehicle for people to express their allegiances.

title: FolgerTech FT-5 Laser Mod with E3D Titan extruder

description.text:
Before you start:

Understand that lasers are extremely dangerous. They can and WILL hurt you if you do not take the proper precautions. The printer should be totally enclosed and you should be wearing laser safety goggles any time the laser is mounted on the machine. Even if its not plugged in or turned on. Accidentally flipping a switch or clicking the wrong option on the LCD or printer control software could have you going to the emergency room. I am not responsible for you blinding or injuring yourself, family members, pets, or setting off you smoke alarms or burning down your house. Thats on you! ;-) With that out of the way...

The only part that needs supports is the mounting bracket. Print it on its side with support material between the two lobes and you'll be good to go.

Here is the laser I bought:

http://www.ebay.com/itm/Focusable-445nm-2-5W-Blue-Beam-Laser-Module-450nm-2500mW-Blue-module-DIY-Machine-/332109603369?hash=item4d53466229%3Ag%3AXCgAAOSwUKxYkFRO

Printer:

FolgerTech FT-5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Before you start:

Understand that lasers are extremely dangerous. They can and WILL hurt you if you do not take the proper precautions. The printer should be totally enclosed and you should be wearing laser safety goggles any time the laser is mounted on the machine. Even if its not plugged in or turned on. Accidentally flipping a switch or clicking the wrong option on the LCD or printer control software could have you going to the emergency room. I am not responsible for you blinding or injuring yourself, family members, pets, or setting off you smoke alarms or burning down your house. Thats on you! ;-) With that out of the way...

The only part that needs supports is the mounting bracket. Print it on its side with support material between the two lobes and you'll be good to go.

Wiring:

You can buy any basic DPDT toggle switch for the enclosure. Wiring up the laser board is pretty simple. Just run the positive and negative leads from the fan port on the MKS board to the center position of the toggle switch. On one side hook up your fan wires and on the other hook up the wires that power the laser control module. Then you need to run the wires from the control box up to the gantry. I made a harness for mine that it can be easily installed or removed. Don't try to run a 3D print with the laser attached to the gantry. The body of the laser module is very heavy and introduces an unacceptable level of backlash into your prints.

Software:

Download Inkscape, a free graphic design software. Then look up the J Tech Potonics Laser Tool extension for inkscape. I don't have time to explain to you how to use the software. Their tutorial is ok. Its enough to get you started at least. The rest is up to you. There are other exensions for Inkscape that I have not tried yet. You can also download and try out PicLaser. PicLaser will create a greyscale image or a photo and convert it to laser gcode. I have not tested it yet. There are only a handful of solutions for Marlin right now. A conversion to smoothieware may be in my future but I was not ready for that upgrade yet.

Testing:

Once the laser is installed you will need to flip the toggle switch on the control box to switch the power from your cooling fan to the laser control module. Once done place your desired material on the build plate and ensure that the print head clears the part. Then turn the fan speed (either in the your printer control software or from the lcd) to 3 or 4. This will turn the laser on. Then twist the focus ring on the laser until it is the smallest size dot possible. Align it with the top right edge of your part and then select your laser gcode from the SD card (yes, you HAVE to use the SD card). The laser will do its thing.

HAVE FUN!! and BE SAFE!!!!

comments.text: This is awesome.  I am about 25% through an FT-5 build and I have the same laser module.  Is there a way, you think, to mount the laser on the carriage without having to swap carriages so that both the print head and the laser are on at the same time?  Any thoughts as to the effect of the added weight?  I can handle slower print speeds, but it would be a far lower maintenance effort to have the 2 on at the same time.
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: Also, the front plate on my design is oversized to allow for the laser to be mounted easier. On the stock design there isn't much room at all for modification. The back plate has solid material where the screws are. This lets you get the screws nice and tight on the mount.
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: I definitely don't recommend keeping the laser on all the time. I made this carriage and mount to be super easy to put the laser on and remove it. You don't even need the screws that hold the mount to the carriage since it moves so slowly. I just added them into the design for good measure. As for mounting them to the melamine parts i definitely wouldn't. The laser is heavy and the melamine is very weak. Even putting the screw in too tight will tear it up. You can break it up by hand without much effort even. I printed mine in nylon to allow for a LITTLE bit of flex in case it catches on something on the build plate. Its a little more forgiving than PLA. ABS just didn't seem to cut it either.
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: Sounds good, thanks.  I will plan on redoing the carriage in PLA and adding this feature.  How do you have your waste board installed?  Just a piece of material sitting on top of the bed?
comments.author: dsnider42

comments.text: I don't have a waste board at the moment. I'm not doing any cutting so there's no need to absorb the laser radiation under the part. Just doing some basic engraving and stuff for now.
comments.author: SkyRider
